awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Defining the role of skin microbiomes in defense against chytridiomycosis in frogs with seasonal infections
awd_abstract_narration:
Microbiomes are a ubiquitous part of all ecosystems including the skin. Although the idea that “good” microbes can defend against pathogens is widely accepted, it is still unclear how microbial communities provide benefits to the host under variable climates. This research will examine the defense mechanisms against a lethal skin fungus that has been associated with global amphibian declines. The studies will investigate the links between natural skin microbes and frog immunity to understand seasonal changes in disease outcomes using a species of frog that can die of infection but can survive under optimal environmental conditions. This project addresses the interplay between disease susceptibility and immunity for species that do not have a free-living tadpole stage but instead are direct-developing frogs. Considering the current changes in weather patterns, seasonality is expected to shift over time, adding more instability to host-pathogen relationships. To address how microbiomes in skin interact with the immunological response to this pathogen, the researchers will study frogs in natural populations and perform controlled laboratory experiments. The results will allow better predictions about the impact of seasonal variations on species interactions that can influence defense against emerging diseases. The researchers will develop and disseminate course materials for a college-level Disease Ecology course that integrates fundamental concepts from ecology and evolution and from the molecular level to ecosystem impacts. In addition, the researchers will work with the Florida Museum of Natural History to develop outreach travel exhibitions targeted to middle schoolers about amphibian disease ecology and microbiomes. 

Amphibians are globally threatened by chytridiomycosis, a fungal disease caused by Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, and hosts often live under dynamic cycles of low and high pathogen risk. This proposal will focus on the direct-developing frog, Eleutherodactylus coqui, a species that persists in the wild with infections modulated by abiotic factors and microbial communities. The researchers will test if host immune defenses interact with skin microbiome by regulating the presence/absence of certain bacterial members, in turn influencing susceptibility to fungal infection. The researchers will assemble sets of microbial consortia (i.e., groupings of putative symbionts with different community structures) to quantify host immune defenses including constitutive immunity and adaptive responses in the field and in the lab. The proposal includes three research objectives: 1) characterize population-level seasonal consortia of skin bacteria, immune defenses in the skin secretions, and their interactions, 2) test for the redistribution of host defenses under contrasting backgrounds of bacterial diversity, and 3) measure life-stage variability in putative symbionts, host skin defenses, and resulting pathogen burden. The project will leverage individual-level data from host defenses and microbiological assays, microbiome amplicon sequencing, and functional genomics to evaluate the timing and magnitude of responses. Integrated studies of skin microbiomes seen through the lens of host skin defenses under different environmental conditions will shed light on the role of the environment, immunity, and microbiome in resistance and tolerance to disease.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

Our project defined the role of skin microbial communities in amphibian immunity against a pathogen that varies seasonally. We focused our studies on the direct-developing frog, Eleutherodactylus coqui, a tropical species that is active year-round. Populations of this species significantly declined in the 1990s after the introduction of the fungal skin pathogen Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis. However, our findings showed that coqui frogs have recovered despite persistent infections, partly due to their ability to recruit a diverse microbiome from the environment. Specifically, the project objectives were to: (1) characterize temporal variation in skin bacterial communities and immune defenses, (2) test for the production of host defenses under contrasting backgrounds of bacterial diversity, and (3) measure life-stage variability in microbes, host defenses, and pathogen burden. To achieve these objectives, we integrated field sampling and lab experiments with sequencing approaches and mathematical models. The major project outcomes included:

 1.     Temporal characterization of a population of Eleutherodactylus coqui at El Yunque, Puerto Rico. We collected samples through a 3yr mark-recapture study in collaboration with the Burrowes lab. This work allowed us to identify periodic cycles of low and high skin microbiome diversity, changes in host defenses, and pathogen load. In addition, the typical seasonal patterns in Puerto Rico have been shifting as a result of climate change. We developed a quantitative method to identify altered environmental conditions using field and satellite climate data, applicable to other organismal systems.

2.     Juvenile frogs are key for population persistence. Our results showed that host survival was independent of infection, suggesting that frogs compensated for adult mortality by increasing juvenile recruitment. Our collaborators in the Rollins-Smith lab showed that juvenile and adult frog expressed different quantities of peptides, which are compounds found in the skin. Younger frogs released more peptides per gram body weight. These results highlight potential mechanisms of persistence under enzootic disease dynamics. If these defenses are effective against the fungus, then population recruitment is maintained over time despite that the adults might die of infection.

3.     Genetic associations with infection status and bacterial diversity. We found significant associations between host genetic diversity, infection, and skin microbiomes. Frogs with increased heterozygosity were better at recruiting beneficial symbionts and fighting infections. Our mathematical models also indicated that environmental conditions indirectly affect symbiont abundance through frog body condition.

4.     Functional contributions of skin bacteria. We inferred changes in the function of skin bacteria over the progression of the skin infection using an experiment. We found that microbiomes during the cool-dry season were less effective in controlling infection (e.g. chitin degradation), providing evidence that skin function and pathogen defense rely on microbiome diversity. 

5.     Functional genomics. We were able to partition skin transcriptomes (expressed genes) and bioinformatically classify reads by their source: coqui frogs, the symbiont Acinetobacter rhizosphaerae, and the chytrid fungus. This information about the interactions can lead to more targeted interventions to manage diseases in the wild.

6.     Uncovering Acinetobacter diversity. Using long-read sequencing approaches, we identified more than 20 species of bacteria of the genus Acinetobacter, including known human pathogens. We tracked the diversity of these bacteria in recaptured frogs, which resulted in the detection of strain-level differences over time and between sexes.

7.     Publications and presentations. We published six papers and delivered more than two dozen presentations (talks/posters) over the last four years in academic institutions and conferences. We have four additional manuscripts in preparation for publication and under review.

Broader Impacts:

This project benefitted society by: (1) improving teaching, training, and learning; (2) broadening the participation of underrepresented groups; (3) building new collaborations with local and international partners; and (4) disseminating scientific information. Our project offered training to over 10 undergraduate research assistants, 4 graduate students, and 2 postdocs. Undergraduate/graduate students received training in amphibian husbandry, field and molecular techniques, and quantitative methods, which resulted in many presentations in scientific conferences, both locally and internationally. The PI and many members of the team belong to underrepresented minorities in STEM. Resources from this award also supported secondary research projects that stemmed from our findings about microbiome diversity and infection dynamics. Our outreach included tabling activities at our local museum and the participation in podcasts for children, focusing on natural history of direct developing frogs. Overall, this award contributed to a better understanding of immunity, the role of microbiomes in disease resistance, and the broader impacts of environmental changes on wildlife health.
